intro: Mosla scabra, commonly known as narrowleaf germander, is a perennial herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Lamiaceae, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, narrow, and slightly hairy leaves. Its small, tubular flowers are usually pink or purple, and they bloom in late spring to early summer. Mosla scabra is often used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory and antiseptic properties.
